revision.text:
{{short description|Fumble that allowed Philadelphia Eagles to win a 1978 game over the New York Giants}} {{about|a 1978 Eagles–Giants game|a 2010 game involving the same two teams|Miracle at the New Meadowlands}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox NFL single game | name = Miracle at the Meadowlands | image = [[File:Miracle at the Meadowlands fumble.png]] | caption = [[Herman Edwards]] recovers [[Joe Pisarcik]]'s fumble. | visitor = [[1978 Philadelphia Eagles season|Philadelphia Eagles]] | visitor_abbr = PHI | visitor_coach = [[Dick Vermeil]] | visitor_record = 7–5 | home = [[1978 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] | home_abbr = NYG | home_coach = [[John McVay]] | home_record = 5–7 | visitor_qtr1 = 0 | visitor_qtr2 = 6 | visitor_qtr3 = 0 | visitor_qtr4 = 13 | visitor_total = 19 | home_qtr1 = 14 | home_qtr2 = 0 | home_qtr3 = 3 | home_qtr4 = 0 | home_total = 17 | date = November 19, 1978 | stadium = [[Giants Stadium]] | city = [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] | referee = [[Cal Lepore]] | attendance = 70,318 | odds = | network = [[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | announcers = [[Don Criqui]] and [[Sonny Jurgensen]] }} The '''Miracle at the Meadowlands''' was a [[fumble]] recovery by [[cornerback]] [[Herman Edwards]] that he returned for a [[touchdown]] at the end of a November 19, 1978, [[National Football League]] (NFL) game against the [[1978 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] in [[Giants Stadium]]. It is considered miraculous because the Giants were ahead and could easily have run out the final seconds; they had the ball and the Eagles had no [[Sport time-out|timeouts]] left. Everyone watching expected [[quarterback]] [[Joe Pisarcik]] to take one more [[Snap (football)|snap]] and [[quarterback kneel|kneel with the ball]], thus [[running out the clock]] and preserving a 17–12 Giants upset. Instead, he botched an attempt to hand off the football to [[fullback (American football)|fullback]] [[Larry Csonka]]. Edwards picked up the dropped ball and ran 26 yards for the winning score.
The term is primarily used by Eagles fans and sportscasters. Giants fans refer to the play simply as "'''The Fumble'''", though that name is generally used outside of New York for [[The Fumble|a play in the 1987 AFC Championship Game]] between the [[Cleveland Browns]] and [[Denver Broncos]].
For the Eagles, the victory snatched from the jaws of certain defeat served as a [[morale]] boost, leading that season to a [[NFL playoffs|playoff]] berth and, two seasons later, [[Super Bowl XV|the franchise's first Super Bowl appearance]]. To Giants fans, it was the [[nadir]] of a long era of mediocrity, but the aftermath would lead to major changes that proved beneficial for the franchise in the long run.
==Background== It was the first meeting between the divisional rivals that season. The Eagles were in third place in the [[NFC East]], behind the [[1978 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]] and [[1978 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]]; the Giants were in fourth. The teams went into the game in similar situations, but heading in different directions. They had playoff hopes, especially since this was the first 16-game NFL season, but likely would have to settle for a [[Wild card (sports)|wild card]] berth due to the solid lead the powerful Dallas Cowboys had in the division. Given the similarity of their records, it was likely the outcome would have playoff implications, since the first tie-breaker for a wild card spot is the head-to-head record.
===Giants=== Going into the game, the Giants were 5–6. A three-game losing streak on the road had made the team's playoff prospects much dimmer since midseason. However, a win at home against the favored Eagles could, the team hoped, reverse the trend and keep an outside shot at a playoff spot alive. Despite the team's [[History of the New York Giants|storied past]], the Giants had not played in the postseason since 1963 and had managed only two winning seasons since then. Although they were the league's fourth oldest franchise, they were almost a non-entity in the post-[[AFL-NFL Merger|merger]] NFL. The move to [[New Jersey]] in 1976 had alienated some longtime fans, even if it made more seats available. Fans had never gone this long without a contender, but while they were growing restless, they were still forgiving.
However, there was little pressure they could bring to bear on the people who could ultimately make changes, longtime team owners [[Wellington Mara]] and his nephew [[Timothy J. Mara|Tim]], who inherited his father [[Jack Mara|Jack's]] stake in the team after Jack Mara died in 1965. The two managed team operations closely, but feuded so bitterly with each other that at one point a partition had to be erected between their seats in the owners' box. The effects of this uncertainty and instability at the highest managerial level affected the team's play, most significantly when it came to some apparently inexplicable personnel decisions. It was not lost on fans that players ([[Craig Morton]] and [[Fran Tarkenton]]) and coaches ([[Tom Landry]] and [[Vince Lombardi]]) who had once been in the Giants' fold were now enjoying or had enjoyed great success elsewhere. The team also had passed over future stars for less able players in the annual [[NFL draft|draft]].
But all this was for naught. With far more demand for tickets than there were available, the team was financially healthy no matter how poorly it performed on the field, and the Maras were widely viewed as complacent by observers who didn't know the depth of the ownership schism.
====Friction between offensive players and assistant coaches==== The week before the game, players, particularly on offense, had complained to reporters about the team's assistant coaches. Head coach [[John McVay]] was popular with them. He had taken over the team in the middle of the 1976 season after [[Bill Arnsparger]] was fired and improved morale while adding talented players to the team. However, the players were not so enthusiastic about many of the longtime friends he had hired as assistants. The players felt the assistant coaches were uninterested in helping younger players develop, at least compared to their counterparts on other teams. As an example, they pointed out that the season before, none of the team's three quarterbacks had had any previous NFL experience, yet no quarterback coach had been hired. They also noted that one of the few coaches who seemed to care, Jerry Wampfler, coached the [[lineman (football)|offensive line]], one of the Giants' most improved units that season.<ref name="Times pregame">{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Michael|title=Giants Voice Mutual Animosity|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/11/19/archives/giants-voice-mutual-animosity-a-natural-leader-third-and-long-run.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 19, 1978|accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref>
[[Offensive coordinator]] [[Bob Gibson (football coach)|Bob Gibson]] was the most frequent target of complaints. He had taken to the relatively nascent practice (now quite common) of calling all the plays from the upstairs press box. Pisarcik had often challenged Gibson about this, sometimes openly, over the past two seasons.<ref name="Times pregame" /> The players felt that Gibson should let Pisarcik call plays. They pointed out that during the previous week's loss to Washington, the team had attempted only three passes on several third-and-long situations during the game. They also felt insulted that on a third-and-7 in [[overtime (sport)|overtime]], the coaches had called a run play.<ref name="Times pregame" /> Gibson for his part had limited confidence in Pisarcik's passing ability, an opinion widely shared (the media in New York referred to him as "[[off-Broadway]] Joe", a [[sarcasm|sarcastic]] reference to former [[New York Jets]]' quarterback, [[Joe Namath|"Broadway Joe" Namath]]). He and other coaches pointed out that the three passing attempts the players pointed to had resulted in two [[interception]]s and a [[Quarterback sack|sack]].<ref name="Times pregame" />
The team's general philosophy at the time was to concentrate on its improving defense and play conservatively on offense until it could be made more competitive. Players on the Giants' offense became frustrated over this decision and wanted more chances to prove themselves.<ref name="Times pregame" />
===Eagles=== At 6–5, things looked a little more promising for the visitors. The two-game win streak they took into the game had gotten them over a .500 first half. Momentum clearly was on their side, and the Giants had not beaten the Eagles since the opening game of [[1975 NFL season|the 1975 season]], three years prior. Still, the Giants were a decent team, and the Eagles knew they could not relax.
They, too, were an old-line NFL franchise coming off [[History of the Philadelphia Eagles|many years]] in the doldrums. They had not been to the playoffs since winning their third NFL title in [[1960 NFL Championship Game|1960]], and had only notched two winning seasons in the 17 years since then. However, their fans were less inclined to be forgiving than Giants' fans. A loss to the slumping Giants would have dealt a severe blow to the confidence the team needed to maintain over the last quarter of its schedule, in which it would face not only the Cowboys, but the equally formidable [[Minnesota Vikings]] as well as the Giants again in Philadelphia. 1978 was also viewed as an important season for head coach [[Dick Vermeil]], as there was little doubt the Eagles were playing much better under his watch, but there was also a great deal of local impatience for concrete results.
==The game== {{Americanfootballbox | titlestyle = {{NFLPrimaryColor|New York Giants}}; {{NFLSecondaryColor|New York Giants}};text-align:center; | state = autocollapse | title = 1978 Week Twelve: Philadelphia Eagles at New York Giants | date = November 19 | time = 1:00 p.m. EDT | road = '''Eagles''' | R1 = 0 | R2 = 6 | R3 = 0 | R4 = 13 | home = Giants | H1 = 14 |H2 = 0 | H3 = 3 | H4 = 0 | stadium = [[Giants Stadium]], [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] | attendance = 70,318 | weather = 49°F, Clear | Vegas line = Philadelphia Eagles −2 (from RJ Bell of Pregame) | referee = [[Cal Lepore]] | TV = [[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers = [[Don Criqui]] and [[Sonny Jurgensen]] | reference = | scoring = ;First quarter * NYG [[Bobby Hammond]] 19-yard pass from Pisarcik ([[Joe Danelo]] kick) * NYG [[Johnny Perkins]] 30-yard pass from Pisarcik (Danelo kick) ;Second quarter * PHI Montgomery 8-yard rush (kick failed) ;Third quarter * NYG Danelo 37-yard FG ;Fourth quarter * PHI [[Mike Hogan (American football)|Mike Hogan]] 1-yard rush (kick failed) * PHI [[Herman Edwards]] 26-yard fumble return ([[Mike Michel]] kick) | stats = ;Top passers * PHI – [[Ron Jaworski]] – 15/31, 164 YDS, 0 TD, 3 INT * NYG – [[Joe Pisarcik]] – 13/23, 181 YDS, 2 TD, INT ;Top rushers * PHI – [[Wilbert Montgomery]] – 22 CAR, 88 YDS, TD * NYG – [[Doug Kotar]] – 13 CAR, 36 YDS ;Top receivers * PHI – [[Harold Carmichael]] – 5 REC, 105 YDS * NYG – [[Jimmy Robinson]] – 4 REC, 73 YDS }} The Giants opened a two touchdown lead in the first quarter on two Pisarcik touchdown passes, and did not give up the lead until the final play of the game. The Eagles, conversely, struggled, missing one of their [[extra point]] attempts and botching the snap on the other. The Eagles found themselves down 17–12, meaning they could only win the game with a touchdown as time wound down.<ref name="Times game story">{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Michael|title=20 Seconds Left As Eagles Win|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/11/20/archives/20-seconds-left-as-eagles-win-jets-bow-todd-reinjured.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 20, 1978|accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref>
Deep in their own territory, the Giants' [[Doug Kotar]] fumbled late in the fourth quarter, raising hopes (or fears) of a comeback by the visitors. Those were quickly put to rest, however, when rookie defensive back [[Odis McKinney]]'s first NFL interception gave the Giants possession of the football after the [[two-minute warning]]. The Eagles had exhausted all their timeouts by this point.<ref name="Times game story" />
Fans in the stands began heading for the exits as the game seemed all but over, with no apparent remaining danger of an Eagles comeback. Nowadays, teams in this situation let the [[play clock]] run down to the last possible second and have the quarterback take a knee. On the sidelines, a disgusted Eagles coach [[Dick Vermeil]] was turning his attention away from the field and toward the postgame [[press conference]], where he would have to explain to reporters why his team had fallen to an inferior opponent.
===The Giants' possession=== Since the rule to allow QBs to simply kneel didn't take effect until 1987, Pisarcik took the snap on first down<ref name="Sequence of plays">{{cite AV media|people=|year=1978|title=NFL Game of the Week Show #12|time=17 minutes|publisher=NFL Films|id=Tape 52935}}</ref> and rolled on the ground (a common play for QBs in the pre-kneel era). Eagles [[linebacker|middle linebacker]] [[Bill Bergey]] charged into Giants' [[Center (American football)|center]] [[Jim Clack]], knocking him backward into Pisarcik in a desperate attempt to force a fumble. Since defensive players usually are not blocked in this situation, they usually in turn do not rush. Offensive players consider any breach of this tacit agreement as a provocation, particularly linemen whose job it is to protect the quarterback, and fights between angry linemen and the opposition were not uncommon.
Gibson did not want to expose his quarterback to further risk of injury, nor did he want to risk his players being fined for violating the league's rules against fighting. Most importantly, the last thing he wanted was for his team to get a penalty, which could stop the clock and require getting another first down to secure the win. He also personally despised the kneeling play, considering it unsporting and somewhat dishonorable (a view popular among a lot of coaches of the period). Also given that the play clock at the time was only 30 seconds (as it would remain through the 1987 season), a play had to be run. So on second down he called "65 Power-Up", a standard play which called for Csonka to take a handoff and run up the middle. Csonka took the ball and ran for 11 yards. For the third play in the Giants' series, the same play was called again.
In the huddle, the Giants were incredulous when the call came in. "Don't give me the ball", begged fullback [[Larry Csonka]], the former [[Miami Dolphins|Dolphins]] star. Other players asked Pisarcik to change the play, but he demurred.<ref name="Times game story" /> Gibson had berated him for changing a play the week before and threatened to have him [[Waivers (American football)|waived]] if he ever did so again. Gibson did not take the time to explain his decision to Pisarcik. As a result, the rest of the offense simply viewed Gibson's call as a power trip. Because he was a second-year starting quarterback who still had not totally proven himself, in the era before [[Free agent|free agency]], Pisarcik lacked the stature to prevail in this kind of dispute.
Csonka claims that, as he walked away from the huddle, he told Pisarcik he would not take the ball if he went through with it. It is not known whether the quarterback heard him or not, however. McVay's headphones, which normally allowed him to communicate with Pisarcik and Gibson, were not working properly at that point either. McVay has since stated that he would certainly have overruled Gibson had he heard what was coming.
Across the line of scrimmage, the Eagles had not huddled, as [[defensive coordinator]] [[Marion Campbell]] called for an all-out 11-man [[Blitz (American football)|blitz]]. Edwards, who as a defensive back normally would have been several yards deep, was instead close enough to Kotar to talk to him (the Giants player assured him that his team was just going to kneel again). Vermeil later said the blitz made the victory possible.
The Giants wasted several seconds in the huddle in dismay over the play-calling. At the line, Clack saw the play clock winding down and took it upon himself to snap it with 31 seconds left in the game to avoid a delay-of-game penalty, which would have stopped the clock and cost the Giants five yards. Had the Giants knelt on the subsequent play, there still would have been one second left on the game clock once the play clock ran down, requiring a fourth-down play to be run (the play clock at the time ran for 30 seconds; it now runs for 40).
Pisarcik, who at the time was distracted making sure Csonka was in position, was unprepared for the snap. It struck his middle finger so hard there was still blood on the nail after the game.<ref name="Times next week story">{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Michael|title=Giants' Progress is Key Asset for McVay|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/11/26/archives/giants-progress-is-key-asset-for-mcvay-friends-in-jeopardy.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 26, 1978|accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref> Nevertheless, he held on to the ball after a slight bobble and tried to hand it off to Csonka. Instead, the ball hit Csonka's hip and came loose.
Edwards recovered it on its first bounce as Pisarcik unsuccessfully attempted to fall on it. Kotar, who could have blocked him or fallen on the ball himself, never even saw the fumble, according to Edwards. Once Edwards got it, he sprinted 26 yards untouched into the end zone for a 19–17 Eagles victory. There was stunned silence from the stands and the Giants' sideline. The only noise came from the celebrating Eagles.
===The call=== With Giants victory all but assured, [[NFL on CBS|CBS]] commentator [[Don Criqui]] (working alongside [[Sonny Jurgensen]]) had begun to read the end credits for the game's control truck and on-field personnel shortly before the game's final play:
{{quote|It's Giants football now, third and two. We thank our producer Bob Rowe, our director Jim Silman, and our CBS crew, spotter and statistician John Mara and Tom McHugh here at Giants Stadium. As the clock winds down on the Philadelphia Eagles, a game they thought would project them into a possible wildcard position, it would bring them 7–5 had they won, but a late interception by the Giants will preserve a Giant victory, an upset win as the Giants lead 17–12, we’re inside 30 seconds, the Eagles have no timeouts. [At this point, the snap and fumble take place.] Wait a minute... here's a free football, I don't believe it! The Eagles pick it up and Herman Edwards runs it in for a touchdown! An incredible development!}}
After the game, while showing league highlights, CBS replayed the play. They showed the reaction of both coaches, while [[Brent Musburger]] famously narrated, "A study in contrast!" According to RJ Bell of Pregame, the point spread of Philadelphia Eagles −2 turned Giants winning bets into pushes.
==The immediate aftermath== For Edwards, the play was a personal redemption, as he had been burned on one of Pisarcik's early touchdown passes and would have been partially to blame for the loss. It also was his first NFL touchdown. Vermeil refused to question McVay's judgment but allowed that he, too, disliked sitting on the ball to preserve a victory.<ref name="Times game story" />
Giants fans were enraged. For a football team to lose in that situation was unprecedented. Pisarcik, who belatedly explained to the press, "I never had control,"<ref name="Times game story" /> needed a police escort to get to his car.<ref name="Times next week story" /> During an NFL Network show about famous on-field bloopers, Csonka said that he immediately had Pisarcik join him on a chartered plane trip to South Florida, where they hung out and fished for a few days before returning to New York.
Gibson was fired the next morning.<ref name="Times Gibson firing">{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Michael|title=Giants Oust Gibson A Day After Bungle|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/11/21/archives/giants-oust-gibson-a-day-after-bungle-giants-oust-gibson-a-day.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 21, 1978|accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref> With angry fans already demanding that someone be held responsible for the debacle, team officials felt he had to go in hopes of saving the season.<ref name=gola20081118>{{cite news|last=Gola|first=Hank|title=30 years later, Giant disappointment of 'The Fumble' still lingers|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/giants/30-years-giant-disappointment-fumble-lingers-article-1.335390|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=November 18, 2008|accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref> So great was the stigma of having called the play that he never worked in football at any level again. After his firing, Gibson moved to Florida where he subsequently became manager of a local bait shop.<ref name="Gibson after">{{cite web|last=Daly |first=Buzz |date=November 4, 2005 |url=http://www.eog.com/news/index.aspx?id=957 |title=Mara's Legacy with Giants Recalled |work=Eye on Gambling |accessdate=February 24, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928225600/http://www.eog.com/news/index.aspx?id=957 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |df= }}</ref> He never spoke about the play again for the rest of his life.<ref>''ESPN NFL Live'', November 19, 2008, 4:00pm EST, second segment. Gibson was reached by telephone by ESPN and gave the following statement: "I haven't talked about the game for thirty years, and I'm not about to start now."</ref> In 2008, in a telephone call from ESPN and 30 years after the game, Gibson said: I haven't talked about the game for 30 years, and I'm not about to start now." Gibson died in 2015 at the age of 88.
===Giants fan reaction=== Fans turned on management and ownership as previously grumbled complaints about the team's ineptitude turned into an incessant roar. Their team was now the laughingstock of the league. The Fumble (a term in use before the end of the week) epitomized all the mismanagement and all the talent the team had let get away.
At a demonstration outside the stadium prior to the next home game against the [[Los Angeles Rams]], many fans threw their tickets into a [[bonfire]]. A [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] furniture dealer named Morris Spielberg organized a Giants' Fans Committee after running an ad in the ''[[Newark Star-Ledger]]'' that drew hundreds of responses. They met at a hotel near the stadium prior to the team's final home game on December 10 against the [[History of the St. Louis Cardinals (NFL)|St. Louis Cardinals]] and distributed [[flyer (pamphlet)|flyer]]s to pass out to fellow fans during the game. Spielberg had arranged for a [[airplane|plane]] to fly over the stadium with a banner reading "15 Years of Lousy Football — We've Had Enough." When it came, fans were to chant, "We've had enough."
The Giants posted a 17–0 shutout win, but when the plane came (an hour behind schedule), fans showed the victory was not enough to make them forget their recent humiliation. There were more than 24,000 empty seats, yet crowd applause and chants briefly stopped play.
==The rest of the season== The surprise finish accelerated the directions both teams were taking over the season's final four games. They met in [[Veterans Stadium]] in the final [[regular season]] game.
===Eagles=== Philadelphia was able to extend its win streak to four games the next week, before losing to Dallas and Minnesota. The Eagles managed a season sweep of the Giants with an easy 20–3 victory in the finale to finish 9–7 and snare the second of two wild-card spots available under the playoff format at that time. "One play gets you feeling like you have confidence", Edwards explained years later. "You're not worried about losing anymore; now you're thinking about how you can win."<ref name="25th anniversary">{{cite news|last=Barber|first=Phil|title=Miracle of Meadowlands Turns 25|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/6827118|publisher=National Football League|date=November 12, 2003|accessdate=May 21, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214152018/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/6827118|archivedate=December 14, 2006|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
The Eagles lost the [[1978–79 NFL playoffs|playoff game]] to the [[Atlanta Falcons]] because of another failed extra point, in addition to a missed field goal as time expired. But it gave them and their fans something to build on for the next season. Philadelphia corrected its kicking woes by drafting barefoot [[Tony Franklin (placekicker)|Tony Franklin]] from Texas A&M in 1979. As a rookie, Franklin booted a 59-yard field goal on ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' against the [[Dallas Cowboys]] during a 31–21 victory at [[Texas Stadium]].
===Giants=== At first, the Giants tried to look ahead and recover. They vowed to win their remaining four games and protect McVay's job. Instead, the collapse continued. The next week, the Giants blew a 10-point lead over the 3–9 [[Buffalo Bills]] late in the game, giving up 27 points in the fourth quarter to lose 41–17. They would win only one more game the rest of the season, finishing with a 6–10 record. The sweep by Philadelphia ensured the Giants would finish last in the division (tied with the Cardinals) for the third straight season, extending their rut and further angering fans.
==After the season==
===Eagles=== The next year, the Eagles again earned a wild-card spot and then won their first post-merger playoff game over the [[1979 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]] before falling to [[1979 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|Tampa Bay]]. Following that season, the Giants traded Pisarcik to them for a draft choice. He would finish his career as a backup to [[Ron Jaworski]] five years later. His entire NFL career is usually embodied in that play, and while he is sometimes reluctant to talk about it, he admits that at least people remember his name thanks to it.
The Eagles' momentum carried them further in [[1980 NFL season|the 1980–81 season]], to the division championship, then the conference title and finally to [[Super Bowl XV]], which they lost 27–10 to the [[1980 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]] at the [[Mercedes-Benz Superdome|Superdome]] in [[New Orleans]]. "We won the game at the end, and we went on to the playoffs", Edwards said. "The next thing, we're playing in the Super Bowl." He, too, would find that the play defined his career, even though he remained part of the Eagles' lineup for another seven years before going into coaching after a final season split between the Falcons and Rams.
===Giants=== McVay's contract expired and, as expected, was not renewed. He said in 2008 that had the Giants won, the team likely would have won two more games, his contract would have been renewed, "and now I'd be dead with a heart attack."{{r|gola20081118}} McVay never coached again, but went on to a front-office job with the [[San Francisco 49ers]], where he helped develop that team into one of the most dominant of the 1980s. [[Andy Robustelli]], a former All-Pro [[defensive end]] who served as the team's director of operations, was also let go.
Csonka's contract was up as well. Since McVay, with whom he had played in the [[World Football League]]'s [[Memphis Southmen]] before signing with the Giants, was gone and his career was ending, he decided to return to Miami, site of his past glories, for one final season. He would win an [[NFL Comeback Player of the Year]] award before retiring.
Despite widespread calls to hire [[Joe Paterno]] or another successful college coach, the Giants settled on [[Ray Perkins (wide receiver)|Ray Perkins]], then an assistant for the [[History of the San Diego Chargers|San Diego Chargers]], to replace McVay. While Perkins was able to follow the Eagles' lead and build a team that eventually made the playoffs in [[1981 NFL season|1981]], the moves that really made a difference for the Giants drew less attention that off-season.
Wellington Mara had been running football operations himself since joining the organization in the late 1930s, long after most teams had hired a [[general manager]]. He continued to do so even after inheriting the team upon the death of his father, [[Tim Mara|Tim]], in 1958. While he had delegated some of his authority to Robustelli in 1974, he still had the final say in football matters. However, the fan revolt that erupted in the wake of the Fumble made the Maras realize that they needed to delegate most of the decisions that sorely divided them. As with many other team matters, they kept arguing over whom to hire as general manager. In the off-season, they called on NFL commissioner [[Pete Rozelle]] to mediate. He suggested [[George Young (football executive)|George Young]], then an executive with the [[Miami Dolphins]], who only took the job after he was granted complete control of the football side of the operation. He proved to be a superb judge of talent, drafting [[Phil Simms]], [[Lawrence Taylor]] and other future Giants stars over the next few seasons.
In 1981, Perkins hired a new defensive coordinator, [[Bill Parcells]], a [[New England Patriots]] assistant who was out of coaching in 1979 after serving as head coach at [[Air Force Falcons football|Air Force]] in 1978. When Perkins resigned after the [[1982 NFL season|1982 season]] to succeed the late [[Bear Bryant]] at the [[University of Alabama]], Parcells took over as head coach. He survived a disastrous first season to lead the talent Young had acquired to two Super Bowl championships, and then find further success with the [[New England Patriots]], Jets and Cowboys before a brief stint as the Dolphins' football operations chief. Parcells is revered today as one of the greatest coaches of the game.
==Legacy== The Miracle at the Meadowlands has left a lasting impact on the way organized football is played at all levels, not just in the NFL. Most notably, it legitimized the [[quarterback kneel]]. Coaches everywhere took heed of Gibson's fate and immediately began instructing quarterbacks to sit on the ball in similar situations. Some traditionalists feel that the kneel-down has been detrimental to the game and have called for rule changes to eliminate or discourage the play.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} Other leagues, such as the [[Arena Football League]], have done just that, and now require the ball to be advanced past the line of scrimmage in order for the clock to continue running in the final minute of play.
[[File:Post-Pisarcik QB kneel formation.svg|250px|left|thumb|Formation used ever since the Fumble/Miracle for quarterback kneel play.]]
===Formation change=== The week after the game, both the Giants and Eagles implemented a new offensive formation to be used only in end-of-game kneeldowns. It is popularly known as the "Victory Formation" or "Victory Offense".
Not only did the infamous game-losing play make kneeling acceptable, but most of the teams using it changed how it was done. Prior to Pisarcik's fumble, teams had employed standard offensive formations such as an I or a split backfield. The Eagles' unlikely touchdown, however, had made the weakness of doing so glaring. Even though Pisarcik had been trying to hand off instead of kneeling, when he fumbled the snap, there was not only no offensive player there to try to recover it, no one was in position to tackle Edwards and prevent the touchdown either.
At the end of the first half of the Bills game the following week, the Giants debuted the new formation when Pisarcik knelt to preserve their lead. Two running backs stood closely behind Pisarcik while a third (usually a speedy player such as a [[wide receiver]]) was stationed as a sort of safety several yards back.
The Eagles, too, had practiced a similar formation in practice, calling it the Herman Edwards play. Other NFL teams soon followed the lead, and today the formation is standard in college and high school games as well.
===Similar plays=== The play has been recalled often by fans and reporters in later years when a team fumbled away a sure victory late in the game, although it never happened quite as spectacularly as it did that first time.
Probably the most famous play to evoke the Miracle of the Meadowlands, although with a very different outcome, occurred almost three decades later in a [[2005–06 NFL playoffs#AFC: Pittsburgh Steelers 21, Indianapolis Colts 18|2006 Steelers-Colts AFC divisional playoff game]]. As in 1978, an [[Indianapolis Colts|Indianapolis]] turnover on downs had given [[Pittsburgh Steelers|Pittsburgh]] the ball on the Indianapolis 2-yard line and an apparent three-point victory over the heavily favored Colts in the game's final two minutes. However, the Steelers had to keep running the ball, as the Colts still had all their timeouts left. A field goal would have at least required the Colts to score a touchdown (plus kick the extra point) to win the game, while a touchdown would essentially clinch victory, so it was in the Steelers' interest to keep running. A pass would run the risk of being intercepted, or seeing the defense knock the ball out of the quarterback's hand. But on the very first play, running back [[Jerome Bettis]], who had not fumbled all season, had the ball knocked loose by Indianapolis middle linebacker [[Gary Brackett]]. Defensive back [[Nick Harper (American football)|Nick Harper]] recovered the ball and appeared to be on the way to an Edwards-like touchdown, but Pittsburgh quarterback [[Ben Roethlisberger]] managed to tackle Harper near midfield.
Steelers fans and players feared that Bettis was about to end his career with the same ignominy that followed Pisarcik. Several plays later, however, Colts [[placekicker|kicker]] [[Mike Vanderjagt]] wound up the game's [[scapegoat#Scapegoating in sports|goat]], evoking [[Wide Right (Buffalo Bills)|another memorable football moment]] when he missed what would have been the tying field goal, ending what had been a strong season for his team. The Steelers eventually went on to [[Super Bowl XL|a Super Bowl victory that year]], and the play would instead enter NFL lore as "[[Pittsburgh sports lore#The Tackle II|The Tackle II]]".
The play most directly analogous to the Miracle involved a player's, rather than a coach's, questionable decision that cost his team a game. On [[Thanksgiving Day]] [[1993 NFL season|1993]], the Cowboys were playing their customary holiday contest, this time against the visiting Dolphins, in [[Rain and snow mixed|sleet]]. As the clock ticked down, Dallas appeared to have won when it blocked a 41-yard Miami field goal. But as several Dolphins players were gathered around the ball, waiting for it to come to rest in order to down it as close as possible to the Dallas goal, Dallas defensive end [[Leon Lett]] sprinted downfield to try to recover it. He slipped on the slick surface and touched the ball. His touch meant that it became a live ball and Miami was able to recover at the Dallas 1 and kick a field goal for a 16–14 victory.
Lett earned comparisons to Pisarcik and the 1978 Giants since his action was as unnecessary and seemed equally inexplicable. It was fourth down and the ball would have been turned over to Dallas anyway. Coming on the heels of [[Super Bowl XXVII|the previous year's Super Bowl]], when a prematurely celebrating Lett had been stripped on a fourth-quarter fumble return as he was about to score a touchdown, the Thanksgiving gaffe cemented his reputation for unthinking play that overshadowed his entire career.
A near-identical play in a 1999 collegiate game allowed the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] (UNLV) to steal a victory from [[Baylor University|Baylor]]. With the final seconds ticking off the clock, Baylor had a 24–21 lead and possession of the football near the UNLV goal line. With UNLV out of timeouts, only a kneeldown was necessary. However, instead of trying to run out the clock, Baylor elected to try for a touchdown in an attempt to [[running up the score|run up the final score]]. Baylor running back Darryl Bush fumbled while trying to punch his way into the end zone, and UNLV's Kevin Thomas picked up the loose football and went 99 yards for the game-winning touchdown on the last play of the game.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
"The Miracle on the Mountain" is another play with similar circumstances. It took place on October 12, 2002 in a game between the home [[Appalachian State Mountaineers football|Appalachian State Mountaineers]] and visiting [[Furman University|Furman Paladins]] at Kidd Brewer Stadium. A low scoring affair, the Paladins elected to attempt a two-point conversion after scoring the go-ahead touchdown with seven seconds left in the game. Leading 15–14, Furman quarterback Billy Napier's pass was intercepted by Josh Jeffries at the four-yard line. He lateraled the ball to Derrick Black, who returned it for a score, giving the Mountaineers a 16–15 win.
A similar play occurred during a ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game between the [[Chargers]] and [[Kansas City Chiefs|Chiefs]] on October 31, 2011. Tied 20–20, the Chargers offense marched the ball down the field to the Chiefs' 15-yard line. With one minute left, the Chiefs had no timeouts and the Chargers could run the clock down to the final seconds. Chargers quarterback [[Philip Rivers]] snapped the ball with the intent to simply fall down and to the left, to line up kicker [[Nick Novak]] for the game-winning field goal. However, on the snap, the football jammed into Rivers' ring finger, visibly dislocating it, causing Rivers to fumble the ball.<ref>{{cite news|author=soybon|title=Würst Night Ever.|url=http://www.arrowheadpride.com/2011/11/1/2528919/wurst-night-ever|website=[[SB Nation]]|date=November 1, 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Michael|title=ANIMATED: Philip Rivers Fumble Costs Chargers Shot At Win In Regulation|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2011/11/1/2528786/phillip-rivers-fumble-video-chargers-chiefs|website=SB Nation|date=November 1, 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref> Chiefs linebacker [[Andy Studebaker]] recovered the fumble in the resulting scrum. The Chiefs went on to win in overtime 23–20.<ref>{{cite news|last=McCauley|first=Kevin|title=Chargers Vs. Chiefs: Video Highlights Of K.C.'s Wild OT Win|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2011/11/1/2529467/san-diego-chargers-vs-kansas-city-chiefs-highlights-monday-night-football/in/2291673|website=SB Nation|date=November 1, 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref> Rivers was seen on the sidelines mouthing the words "This is the worst day ever."<ref>{{cite news|title=Philip Rivers clarifies 'worst' comment|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/7183760/philip-rivers-san-diego-chargers-claims-said-worst-play-ever-not-day|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=ESPN|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref> As a result of the win, the Chiefs moved into a three-way tie for the lead in the [[AFC West]].
Another occurrence capped [[Kansas State Wildcats football|Kansas State]]'s 38–35 [[comeback (sports)|comeback]] victory November 21, 2015, over [[Iowa State Cyclones football|Iowa State]]. Kansas State had rallied from a 35–14 halftime deficit to pull to within one touchdown. With 1:31 left, Iowa State having possession on first down and the Wildcats having just one time out remaining, the Cyclones chose instead to run the ball before fumbling the ball away; Kansas State would tie the game on the ensuing possession. On Iowa State's next series, starting with 50 seconds remaining, the Cyclones again chose to run a play rather than take a knee and send the game into overtime, but quarterback [[Joel Lanning]] was sacked on second down and lost possession of the ball, ultimately leading to a game-winning field goal by the Wildcats.<ref>{{cite news|last=Birch|first=Tommy|title=Kansas State stuns error-prone ISU|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/sports/college/iowa-state/football/2015/11/21/iowa-state-cyclones-kansas-state-wildcats-game-recap/76111140/|newspaper=[[Des Moines Register]]|date=November 21, 2015|accessdate=November 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Birch|first=Tommy|title=Status report: Iowa State fumbles away a victory|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/sports/college/iowa-state/football/2015/11/21/status-report-iowa-state-fumbles-away-victory/76110758/|newspaper=Des Moines Register|date=November 21, 2015|accessdate=November 23, 2015}}</ref> Iowa State coach [[Paul Rhoads]]' play-calling in the final 90 seconds of the game, the culmination of a difficult 2015 season for ISU, ultimately led to his firing.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Peterson|first1=Randy|last2=Birch|first2=Tommy|title=Paul Rhoads fired as Iowa State coach, will coach, will coach finale|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/sports/college/iowa-state/cyclone-insider/2015/11/22/paul-rhoads-fired-iowa-state-coach/76217264/|newspaper=Des Moines Register|date=November 22, 2015|accessdate=November 22, 2015}}</ref>
==Other uses== On September 23, 1991, in a Monday Night game between the [[1991 New York Jets season|New York Jets]] and the [[1991 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]], the Jets were leading 13–6 and had the ball with two minutes remaining. With thousands of fans already having given up and headed to the [[Soldier Field]] parking lot, running back [[Blair Thomas]] took a handoff. Bears defensive tackle [[Steve McMichael]] stopped Thomas cold and then proceeded to wrestle the ball from his grasp, falling on the fumble at the Jets' 36-yard line with 1:54 remaining. On the final play of regulation, [[Jim Harbaugh]] threw a six-yard touchdown pass to [[Neal Anderson]]; Bears kicker [[Kevin Butler (American football)|Kevin Butler]] tied the game with the extra point. In overtime, Harbaugh scored from the one-yard line to clinch the win for Chicago.
On October 23, 2000, the [[2000 New York Jets season|New York Jets]] overcame a 30–7 fourth-quarter deficit in a ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' (MNF) contest against the [[2000 Miami Dolphins season|Miami Dolphins]] to win 40–37 in [[overtime (sports)|overtime]]. It was the greatest comeback in ''MNF'' history, and was later voted the best ''Monday Night Football'' game ever by the show's fans. Jets fans have referred to this game, too, as "The Miracle at the Meadowlands", though it is known throughout the NFL as the [[Monday Night Miracle (American football)|Monday Night Miracle]].
A punt return by [[Brian Westbrook]] of the Eagles with 1:16 left on the clock on October 19, 2003 is occasionally referenced as a "Miracle at the Meadowlands".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.section247sportsblog.com/tag/miracle-at-the-meadowlands-iii/|title=Miracle...Part III. Jackson's Punt Return Clinches Win But Give Vick Credit For The Victory|author=Michael Lipinski|publisher=Section 247 Sportsblog|date=December 19, 2010|accessdate=December 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/gametracker/recap/NFL_20031019_PHI@NYG|title=Eagles pull off another Miracle at the Meadowlands|publisher=CBS Sports|date=October 19, 2003|accessdate=December 22, 2010}}</ref> The play and subsequent extra point gave the Eagles [[2003 Philadelphia Eagles season#Week 7: at New York Giants|a 14–10 victory over the Giants]] at [[Giants Stadium]].
On December 14, 2008, the [[2008 New York Jets season|New York Jets]] were trailing the [[2008 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] 27–24 with 1:45 left. The Jets had struggled to stop the Bills running game the entire day and the Bills were currently in possession of the ball on their own 20-yard line when Bills quarterback [[J. P. Losman]] ran a [[play action]] option. Jets safety [[Abram Elam]] sacked Losman and caused a fumble, which Jets defensive end [[Shaun Ellis]] picked up and ran for a touchdown to give the Jets a 31–27 victory (on the next Bills possession, Losman was picked off by cornerback [[Darrelle Revis]]). The ''[[New York Post]]'' ran an article the next day referring to the game as the Miracle at the Meadowlands sequel.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/sports/jets/item_gpIkHtjK8tYNgIRDgzDUZP|title=Sack, Scoop provide Miracle at Meadowlands Sequel|author=Vaccaro, Mike|journal=New York Post}}</ref>
The "[[Miracle at the New Meadowlands]]" was played on December 19, 2010. The Giants were leading the Eagles by a score of 31–10 with 7:28 left in the 4th quarter. The Eagles mounted a comeback by scoring 28 points culminating in a game-winning touchdown as time expired to win 38–31. Giants punter [[Matt Dodge]] kicked to [[DeSean Jackson]] on the final play, which resulted in a 65-yard punt return touchdown, as time expired.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Use British English|date=March 2016}} '''Norris''' (dates unknown) was an English [[cricket]]er who played for [[London Cricket Club]] during the 1740s.
==Career== Norris is mentioned in 1744 and 1745. On Saturday, 2 June 1744, he played for [[London Cricket Club|London]] against [[Slindon Cricket Club|Slindon]] in the earliest match that has a surviving scorecard.<ref name=GB18>[[G B Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'', Cotterell, 1935</ref> On Wednesday, 26 June 1745, he played for [[Richard Newland (cricketer)|R Newland's XI]] versus [[Robert Colchin|Long Robin's XI]].<ref name=ASW>[[F S Ashley-Cooper]], ''At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742-1751'', ''Cricket'' Magazine, 1900</ref>
As Norris had established his reputation by 1744, he must have been active for some years previously and his career probably began in the 1730s. Very few players were mentioned by name in contemporary reports and there are no other references to Norris.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153248/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1741.html#1744 From Lads to Lord's – 1744]
==Further reading== * [[F S Ashley-Cooper]], ''At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742-1751'', ''Cricket'' Magazine, 1900 * [[G B Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'', Cotterell, 1935 * [[Timothy J McCann]], ''Sussex Cricket in the Eighteenth Century'', Sussex Record Society, 2004 * [[H T Waghorn]], ''Cricket Scores, Notes, etc. (1730-1773)'', Blackwood, 1899 * [[H T Waghorn]], ''The Dawn of Cricket'', Electric Press, 1906
{{DEFAULTSORT:Norris}} [[Category:English cricketers]] [[Category:English cricketers of 1701 to 1786]] [[Category:London Cricket Club cricketers]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]]

{{Infobox venue | name = Palace of Water Sports | native_name = Дворец водных видов спорта | native_name_lang = rus | image = Kazan-aquatics-palace1.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = View from Sibgat Khakim street, 2013 | fullname = Palace of Water Sports Kazan | nickname = Kazan Aquatics Palace | location = [[Kazan]], [[Tatarstan]], [[Russia]] | coordinates = {{coord|55.8164|N|49.1597|E|display=inline,title}} | capacity = 4,185 | built = 2009–2012 | opened = 12 April 2013 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Ministry of Sport (Russia)|Ministry of Sports of the Russian Federation]] | operator = State Academy of Physical Culture, Sports and Tourism of the Volga Region | architect = [[Sergei Tchoban]] and [[Sergey Kuznetsov (architect)|Sergei Kuznetsov]] (SPEECH studio) with architects from [[Arup Group|Ove Arup]] | main_contractors = {{hlist|SPEECH Tchoban & Kuznetsov|Ove Arup|AlkosProject}} | tenants = [[2013 Summer Universiade]]
[[2015 World Aquatics Championships]]. | website = {{URL|http://akvapalace.ru}} }} The '''Palace of Water Sports''' ({{Lang-ru|Дворец водных видов спорта}}; {{lang-tt|Су спорт төрләре сара}}) is an indoor aquatics centre in [[Kazan]], [[Tatarstan]], [[Russia]] which was built for the [[2013 Summer Universiade]]. Located on the banks of the [[Kazanka River]], the competitions in [[Synchronized swimming at the 2013 Summer Universiade|synchronized swimming]], [[Diving at the 2013 Summer Universiade|diving]], [[Swimming at the 2013 Summer Universiade|swimming]] and [[Water polo at the 2013 Summer Universiade|water polo]] took place here. It later hosted the [[Diving at the 2015 World Aquatics Championships|diving events for the 2015 World Aquatics Championships]]. The temporary open arena for water polo with 3,500 was built nearby, using its service and support systems. ==Construction== The Aquatic Sports Palace was built between September 2009 and October 2012. With an investment of $115 million (€90 million approximately),{{cite web|url=http://www.sportskeeda.com/swimming/world-aquatics-venue-to-open-friday|title=World Aquatics venue to open Friday|date=9 April 2013|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2018}} the design and construction was awarded by tender to a consortium of British and Russian firms specializing in architecture and engineering: SPEECH Tchoban & Kuznetsov, an architectural and design studio based in Moscow with experience in Russia and Germany, [[Arup Group|Ove Arup]], a British company designers of the [[Beijing National Stadium|Bird's Nest Stadium]] in [[Beijing]] and PSO Kazan ООО, a Russian design and construction company established in the Republic of Tatarstan.http://eng.tatar-inform.ru/news/tatarstan/2009/09/17/26702/ ==Technical features== [[File:Дворец водных видов спорта в Казани.jpg|thumb|left|The interior of the sports palace.]] The capacity of the venue is for 3,715 spectators, including press booths and seats in the VIP area with special folding stands for athletes, which can increase capacity to 4,185 people.{{cite web|url=http://akvapalace.ru/about/|title=Дворец Водных Видов Спорта Казань - официальный сайт|website=akvapalace.ru|accessdate=23 March 2018}} It is equipped with trampolines and a platform. The building consists of three pools: *Diving – 33.3×25 m pool (allowable operating depth is 5.5 m) *Synchronized swimming – 50×25 m (maximum operating depth is 3.0 m) *Training pool – 50×25 m (practicing pool depth is 2.2 m) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline|Palace of Water Sports}} * {{Official website|http://akvapalace.ru}} * [http://www.arup.com/Projects/Kazan_Aquatics_Centre Kazan Aquatics Centre] on Ove Arup website. * [http://www.sportacadem.ru/dvorec_vodnyh_vidov_sporta/ Aquatics Palace] on the site of the Volga Region's State Academy of Physical Culture, Sports and Tourism. * [http://www.speech.su/projects/sporting_objects/100-dvorec-vodnyx-vidov-sporta.html Palace of Water Sports for the Universiade 2013] by SPEECH architectural firm. [[Category:Sports venues in Russia]] [[Category:2013 Summer Universiade]] [[Category:2015 World Aquatics Championships]] [[Category:Swimming venues in Russia]] [[Category:Sport in Kazan]] [[Category:Sport in Tatarstan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2013]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Kazan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tatarstan]] {{Russia-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox horseraces |class = |horse race = Port Stakes |image = |caption = |location = [[Newmarket Racecourse|Two Middle Miles of the Beacon Course]]
[[Newmarket, Suffolk|Newmarket]], [[England]] |inaugurated = |race type = [[Flat racing|Flat]] / [[Thoroughbred]] |sponsor = |website = |distance = 1 mile 7 furlongs 127 yards (3134 metres) |surface = Turf |track = |qualification = Four-year-olds |weight = |purse = }} The '''Port Stakes''' was a [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[Great Britain]] open to four-year-olds. It was run on the Two Middle Miles (T.M.M.) of the Beacon course at [[Newmarket Racecourse|Newmarket]] over a distance of 2 miles, and was scheduled to take place each year in early or mid April at the Craven meeting. The Two Middle Miles course was relatively flat and was considered less testing then the "Ditch-In" course, over which the similar [[Claret Stakes]] was run.http://www.nhrm.co.uk/Some_Museum_Treasures/The_Beacon_Post.aspx The race often attracted winners of the previous seasons [[British Classic Races]]: classic winners who went on to win the Port Stakes included [[Whisker (horse)|Whisker]], [[Prince Leopold (horse)|Prince Leopold]], [[Mameluke (horse)|Mameluke]], [[Green Mantle]], [[Priam (horse)|Priam]], [[Galata (horse)|Galata]], [[Grey Momus]], [[Ralph (horse)|Ralph]] and [[Attila (horse)|Attila]]. ==Winners 1815–1843== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- style="background:#7d7; text-align:center;" ! {{Infobox football club |clubname=Public Works Department |image= |fullname=Public Works Department Football Club |nickname= |founded= |ground=[[Changlimithang Stadium|Changlimithang]]
[[Thimpu]], [[Bhutan]] |coordinates= |capacity=25,000 |chairman= |manager= |coach= |league=[[A-Division (Bhutan)|Bhutan A-Division]] |season=[[1986 A-Division (Bhutan)|1986]] |position=5th{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutan86.html|title=Bhutan 1986|last=Burns|first=Peter|last2=Makdissi|first2=Albert| date=31 July 2003| website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}} | }} ''' Public Works Department''' was a football club from [[Bhutan]], based at [[Changlimithang Stadium|Changlimithang]], who played in the inaugural [[A-Division (Bhutan)|Bhutan A-Division]], then the top level of football in Bhutan, but since replaced by a full [[Bhutan National League|national league]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutan2012.html|title=Bhutan 2012|last=Schöggl|first=Hans|last2=Stokkermans|first2=Karel|last3=Jigmi|first3=Sonam|date=28 Feb 2013|website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}} ==History== They finished fifth in the [[1986 A-Division (Bhutan)|inaugural]] season, winning three and drawing two of their nine games. They achieved victories over [[Education (Bhutanese football club)|Education]] and [[Yangchengphug College]] 2–1 and 2–0 respectively, whilst drawing with [[Health School]] and [[Motithang College]] 0–0 and [[T. I. and Power]] 3–3. There are no records available for any competitions held between 1987–1995,{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/bhutanchamp.html|title=Bhutan – List of Champions|last=Schöggl|first=Hans|last2=Abbink|first2=Dinant|date=28 May 2014|website=www.rsssf.com|publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]]|accessdate=27 June 2014}} so it is not known whether they competed again, and there is no record of them competing in any future season for which records exist. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Thimphu League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bhutan]] [[Category:Sport in Thimphu]] {{Bhutan-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox golf facility | name = Royal Portrush Golf Club | image = | imagesize = 250px | caption = | location = [[Portrush]], [[County Antrim]],
[[Northern Ireland]], [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] | coordinates = {{Coord|55.200|-6.635|display=inline,title}} | establishment = 1888, {{Time ago|1888}} | owner = | operator = | holes = 36 | tournaments = *[[The Open Championship]]
([[1951 Open Championship|1951]], ''2019'') * [[The Amateur Championship]]
(1960, 1993, 2014) * [[Boys Amateur Championship]]
(2018) * [[Irish Open (golf)|Irish Open]]
(1930, 1937, 1947, 2012) | website = {{URL|http://www.royalportrushgolfclub.com/}} | course1 = Dunluce Links | designer1 = [[Harry Colt]] | par1 = 72 | length1 = {{convert|7337|yd}} | record1 = 65 – Caolan Rafferty (New Course record) (2017)
61 – [[Rory McIlroy]] (Old Course record) (2006) | slope1 = | course2 = Valley Links | designer2 = [[Harry Colt]] | par2 = 71 | length2 = {{convert|6346|yd}} | rating2 = | slope2 = | pushpin_map = Northern Ireland#United Kingdom | pushpin_relief = 1}} '''Royal Portrush Golf Club''' is a private [[golf club (institution)|golf club]] in [[County Antrim]], [[Northern Ireland]]. The 36-hole club has two [[links (golf)|links]] [[golf course|courses]], the Dunluce Links (the championship course) and the Valley Links. The former is one of the courses on the Open championship rota and will next host the tournament in 2019. In [[1951 Open Championship|1951]], Royal Portrush hosted the [[Open Championship]], the oldest of golf's [[Men's major golf championships|major championships]]; the only Open not held on the island of [[Great Britain]]. The Open will return to Portrush in 2019; it hosted the [[Irish Open (golf)|Irish Open]] in [[2012 European Tour|2012]], the first in Northern Ireland since 1953.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/golf/18667082 |work=BBC Sport |title=Irish Open: Jamie Donaldson wins at Portrush by four shots |date=1 July 2012 |accessdate=15 July 2012}} The Dunluce Links course is considered to be one of the best courses in the world. It was ranked fourth by ''Golf World'' in their list of "The 100 greatest courses in the British Isles" in November 1996. ''Golf Magazine'' ranked it twelfth in their list of the Top 100 Courses in the World, and ''[[Golf Digest]]'' ranked it as the fourth best course outside the United States in 2007.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.golfdigest.com/golf-courses/golf-courses/2007-05/100greatestinternational |magazine=Golf Digest |title=100 Best Courses Outside the U.S. |date=28 January 2008}} ==Location== Situated on the North Antrim Causeway Coast, Royal Portrush occupies a triangle of giant sand hills with views of the hills of [[Inishowen]] in [[County Donegal]] in the west, the [[Isle of Islay]] and Southern [[Hebrides]] in the north, with the [[Giant's Causeway]] and the [[The Skerries, Northern Ireland|Skerries]] in the east. The course is overlooked by the ruins of the 13th century [[Dunluce Castle]], which gives its name to Dunluce course. ==History== The Royal Portrush Golf Club was founded {{Time ago|1888}} in 1888 as "The County Club." It became "The Royal County Club" in 1892 under the patronage of the [[George V of the United Kingdom|Duke of York]] and assumed its present name in 1895 under the patronage of the [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Prince of Wales]]. In [[1947 Open Championship|1947]], Rathmore Golf Club member [[Fred Daly (golfer)|Fred Daly]] became the first Irishman to win The Open Championship, and [[1951 Open Championship|four years later]] the club hosted the championship itself, the only time the event has been held in Northern Ireland. The club has also hosted the [[Senior British Open Championship]] between 1995 and 1999 and again in 2004. The club was also host to the 2010 [[Palmer Cup]]. Daly's feat was repeated by club member [[Darren Clarke]] in [[2011 Open Championship|2011]]. Clarke also named Royal Portrush his favourite golf course in the world. The second course at Royal Portrush is the Valley Links, and is used mostly by members of the 'town' club Rathmore and the ladies and juniors of Royal Portrush. It is shorter and considered less demanding than the Dunluce Links. Rathmore clubhouse and the ladies clubhouse are situated adjacent to the first tee. A nine-hole pitch and putt course, named Skerries, starts from the same location. There is also a driving range at the club. ==Rathmore Golf Club== The Valley Links is the home of Rathmore Golf Club whose clubhouse is situated near the first tee. Famous members include 1947 Open Champion [[Fred Daly (golfer)|Fred Daly]] and 2010 U.S. Open champion [[Graeme McDowell]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rathmoregolfclub.co.uk |publisher=Rathmore Golf Club |title=Club History |accessdate=20 October 2015}} ==Signature holes== On the Dunluce course at Portrush there are several signature holes on both the front and back nine. In particular are the fourth, fifth and sixteenth holes. The fourth hole is a long par four which is more than 480 yards from the championship tees, with out of bounds right and thick rough on the left. There are several bunkers in the undulating fairway and the green is placed between two small sand hills. The fifth hole is a relatively short downhill par four with a dogleg to the right. It has no bunkers but a heavily undulating green perched on the edge of a large drop down to the beach and has views across the White Rocks beach, and the [[Dunluce Castle]] after which the course was named. The sixteenth hole, named Calamity Corner, but locally known as just "Calamity" is a long 236 yard, uphill par three. It is played to a green over a huge ravine short and right, with mounds and hollows to the back and left of the green. ==The Open Championship== [[The Open Championship]] was staged at Royal Portrush only once, in [[1951 Open Championship|1951]]; [[Max Faulkner]] won his sole [[Men's major golf championships|major championship]]. The Open is scheduled to return to Portrush {{nowrap|in July [[2019 Open Championship|2019]].{{cite news |title=Open Championship to be staged at Royal Portrush in 2019 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/golf/34576139 |work=BBC Sport |date=20 October 2015}}}} A number of course changes are being made in preparation for the 2019 Open. The 17th and 18th holes of the current Dunluce Links, the Championship course, are to be replaced by two new holes (the 7th and 8th) on land that is currently part of the Valley Links. Holes 7 to 16 will then be holes 9 to 18 on the redesigned course. The land freed-up by removing the 17th and 18th will be used for the tented village. There will be a number of other changes, including lengthening the 2nd hole by {{convert|40|yd}} and realigning the 10th (the new 12th). While the par of the course will remain at 72, the overall length will increase by almost {{convert|200|yd}} to {{convert|7337|yd}}. The total number of bunkers will increase from 59 to 62. Since the Valley Links is losing two holes to the Dunluce Links, a number of changes are also having to be made to that course.{{cite web |url=http://www.theopen.com/News/News/2015/10/Royal-Portrush-to-host-The-148th-Open-in-2019 |publisher=theopen.com |title=Royal Portrush to host The 148th Open in 2019 |date=20 October 2015}} {| class="wikitable" !rowspan=2|Year!!rowspan=2|Winner!!colspan=5|Score |- ! R1 !! R2 !! R3 !! R4 !! Total |- |align=center|[[1951 Open Championship|1951]] || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Max Faulkner]] ||71||70||70||74||285 (−3) |- |align=center|[[2019 Open Championship|2019]] || align=center|''18–21 July'' {{flagicon|}} || || || || || |} ==Irish Open== The club's Dunluce course held the [[2012 European Tour|2012]] [[Irish Open (golf)|Irish Open]] which was won by [[Jamie Donaldson]]. This was the first time that a [[European Tour]] event had been played in Northern Ireland and the first time since 1953 that the Irish Open had been played in Northern Ireland; it was last played at Royal Portrush in 1947.{{cite web |url=http://www.europeantour.com/europeantour/season=2012/tournamentid=2012046/news/newsid=152153.html |publisher=PGA European Tour |title=Royal Portrush and Carton House to stage Irish Open in 2012 and 2013 |date=6 January 2012}} ==Scorecards== '''Dunluce Links – Championship tees''' {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" !Hole!!Name!!Yards!!Par!! !!Hole!!Name!!Yards!!Par |- |1||align=left|Hughie's||420||4||rowspan=10| ||10||align=left|Himalayas||448||4 |- |2||align=left|Giant's Grave||577||5||11||align=left|Tavern||473||5/4 |- |3||align=left|Islay||176||3||12||align=left|Dhu Varren||530||5 |- |4||align=left|[[Fred Daly (golfer)|Fred Daly]]'s||499||4||13||align=left|Feather Bed||192||3 |- |5||align=left|White Rocks||403||4||14||align=left|Causeway||464||4 |- |6||align=left|[[Harry Colt]]'s||191||3||15||align=left|Skerries||427||4 |- |7||align=left|Curran Point||572||5||16||align=left|Calamity Corner||230||3 |- |8||align=left|Dunluce||435||4||17||align=left|Purgatory||405||4 |- |9||align=left|P.G. Stevenson's||430||4||18||align=left|Babington's||465||4 |- | colspan=2|'''Out'''||'''3,703'''||'''36'''|| colspan=2|'''In'''||'''3,634'''||'''36/35''' |- |colspan=5|{{small|Source:}}{{cite web |url=http://d2tbfnbweol72x.cloudfront.net/RoyalPortrush/files/2015/03/Dunluce-Scorecard.jpg?V=1.2 |publisher=Royal Portush Golf Club |agency=(scorecard) |title=Dunluce Course |accessdate=16 July 2016}} ||colspan=2|'''Total''' ||'''7,337'''||'''72/71''' |} '''Valley Links – Championship tees''' {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" !Hole!!Name!!Yards!!Par!! !!Hole!!Name!!Yards!!Par |- |1||align=left|Zara Bolton's||349||4||rowspan=10| ||10||align=left|Middle Green||465||4 |- |2||align=left|Green Lane||385||4||11||align=left|Right About||486||5 |- |3||align=left|Fairy Ring||141||3||12||align=left|St. Andrews||421||4 |- |4||align=left|War Hollow||534||5||13||align=left|Recess||165||3 |- |5||align=left|Prospect||443||4||14||align=left|Giant's Elbow||391||4 |- |6||align=left|Patrick's||409||4||15||align=left|Bunkers Hill||171||3 |- |7||align=left|Cradle||320||4||16||align=left|Valley||493||5 |- |8||align=left|Switch Back||496||5||17||align=left|Saucer||194||3 |- |9||align=left|Mann's||378||4||18||align=left|Home||333||4 |- | colspan=2|'''Out'''||'''3,227'''||'''36'''|| colspan=2|'''In'''||'''3,119'''||'''35''' |- |colspan=5| ||colspan=2|'''Total''' ||'''6,346'''||'''71''' |} ==See also== * [[Royal County Down Golf Club]] * [[Portstewart Golf Club]] * [[Ballyliffin Golf Club]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.royalportrushgolfclub.com/}} * [http://www.royalportrush.com/ RoyalPortrush.com] – unofficial fan site * [http://golfclubatlas.com/courses-by-country/northern-ireland/royal-portrush-golf-club/ Golf Club Atlas Guide] – Royal Portrush Golf Club (Dunluce Links) {{Open Championship Courses}} [[Category:1888 establishments in Ireland]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1888]] [[Category:Organisations based in the United Kingdom with royal patronage]] [[Category:The Open Championship venues]] [[Category:Sports clubs in County Antrim]] [[Category:Golf clubs and courses in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Golf clubs and courses designed by Harry Colt]] [[Category:Portrush]] [[Category:Irish Open (golf) venues]]

{{coord|44|49|46|N|20|27|05|E|display=title}} {{Infobox tennis tournament | name = Serbia Open | type = defunct | founded = 2009 | abolished = 2012 | current = | logo = Serbia-open-logo.png | logo size = 70px | city = [[Belgrade]] | country = Serbia | venue = SRPC Milan Gale Muškatirović | category = [[ATP World Tour 250 series]] | surface = [[Clay court|Clay]] / [[Tennis court|Outdoors]] | draw = 32S / 12Q / 16D | prize money = | website = [http://www.serbiaopen.rs/ www.serbiaopen.rs] }} The '''Serbia Open''' ({{lang-sr|Отворено првенство Србије}}, {{lang|sr-Latn|Otvoreno prvenstvo Srbije}}) was an [[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP]] [[ATP World Tour 250 series|World Tour 250 series]] men's tennis tournament held in [[Belgrade, Serbia]] and played on outdoor [[clay court]]s. The event was held for the first time in [[2009 ATP World Tour|2009]], from May 4–10.[http://www.atpworldtour.com/1/en/news/newsarticle_1612.asp ATP World Tour To Feature New Belgrade Tournament In 2009] It was the first for [[Serbia]], as the country never before hosted an [[Association of Tennis Professionals]] or a [[Women's Tennis Association]] tournament. [[Andreas Seppi]] was the event's last singles champion, having won the tournament in 2012. The tournament was owned and run by the family of [[Novak Djokovic]], who through their company Family Sport purchased the ATP Tour date from the organizers of the [[Dutch Open (tennis)|Dutch Open]] in 2008, then arranged with the local city of Belgrade authorities for the plot of land where the venue was built, and convinced the [[Cabinet of Serbia (2008–2012)|Serbian government]] under prime minister [[Mirko Cvetković]] to support the event through state-owned enterprises, primarily [[Telekom Srbija]]. At the time of their purchase in 2008, Djokovic was the #3 player in the world having won his first Grand Slam title earlier that year. Djokovic's uncle Goran was the tournament director from its inception,{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/tennis/article6217593.ece |title=The Net Post: Novak Djoković is glowing with pride at hosting his own tournament |first=Neil |last=Harman |publisher=''[[The Times]]'' |date=2009-05-04 |accessdate=2009-05-08}} until he resigned the post in late May 2012,[http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/sport.296.html:380973-Srbija-open-pred-gasenjem Srbija open pred gašenjem?];''Večernje novosti'', 22 May 2012 a month after the tournament's 2012 edition. Djokovic won the tournament twice, in 2009. and 2011. In 2013, Serbia Open was replaced on the ATP schedule by the newly established [[Power Horse Cup]] in [[Düsseldorf]]. ==Past finals== ===Singles=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Year ! style="width:200px;"|Champion ! style="width:200px;"|Runner-up ! style="width:125px;"|Score |- |[[2009 Serbia Open|2009]] || {{flagicon|SRB}} '''[[Novak Djokovic]]''' || {{flagicon|POL}} [[Łukasz Kubot]] ||6–3, 7–6(7–0) |- |[[2010 Serbia Open|2010]] || {{flagicon|USA}} '''[[Sam Querrey]]''' || {{flagicon|USA}} [[John Isner]] ||3–6, 7–6(7–4), 6–4 |- |[[2011 Serbia Open|2011]] || {{flagicon|SRB}} '''[[Novak Djokovic]]''' || {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Feliciano López]] || 7–6(7–4), 6–2 |- |[[2012 Serbia Open|2012]] || {{flagicon|ITA}} '''[[Andreas Seppi]]''' || {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Benoît Paire]] || 6–3, 6–2 |} ===Doubles=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Year ! style="width:200px;"|Champions ! style="width:200px;"|Runners-up ! style="width:125px;"|Score |- | [[2009 Serbia Open|2009]] || {{flagicon|POL}} '''[[Łukasz Kubot]]'''

{{flagicon|AHO}} [[Jean-Julien Rojer]] || 6–2, 7–6(7–3) |- | [[2010 Serbia Open|2010]] || {{flagicon|MEX}} '''[[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]]'''
{{flagicon|USA}} '''[[Travis Rettenmaier]]''' ||{{flagicon|POL}} [[Tomasz Bednarek]]
{{flagicon|POL}} [[Mateusz Kowalczyk]] || 7–6(8–6), 6–1 |- | [[2011 Serbia Open|2011]] || {{flagicon|CZE}} '''[[František Čermák]]'''

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = THF Sport Hall
THF Spor Salonu | image = | location = Hollanda Cad. 47,
[[Çankaya, Ankara|Çankaya]], [[Ankara]], Turkey | coordinates = {{coord|39|52|25|N|32|51|16|E|type:landmark_scale:100000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = {{start date and age|2011|10|21}} | opened = {{start date and age|2012|10|03}} | owner = [[Turkey Handball Federation]] | cost = {{Turkish lira}}11 million
(approx.US$ 6.145 as of October 2012 | architect = | main_contractors = | capacity = 2,700 | tenants = }} The '''THF Sport Hall''' ({{lang-tr|THF Spor Salonu}}) is an [[indoor arena]] for [[Team handball|handball]] matches located in [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]]. It is situated within the THF complex. The venue, having a seating capacity of 2,700, was opened in 2012. The [[Ministry of Youth and Sports (Turkey)|Turkish Ministry of Youth and Sports]] and the [[Turkey Handball Federation]] (THF) decided the building of a handball-dedicated sports venue in Ankara on May 23, 2011.{{cite news |url=http://nethaberci.com/sondakika-spor-haberleri/thf-yeni-hentbol-salonuna-kavusuyor-267345.html |newspaper=Net Haberci |title=THF, yeni hentbol salonuna kavuşuyor |date=2012-05-23 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.ihalekarari.com/kamu_ihale_kurulu_uyusmazlik_karari_32232/ |publisher=Ihale Kararı |title=Thf Spor Salonu Ve Kompleksi İkmal İnşaatı Yapım İşi |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }} The construction began with ground breaking on October 21, 2011, and completed in June 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.otainsaat.com.tr/proje_incele.php?id=MTA0 |publisher=Ota İnşaat |title= THF Spor Salonu ve Kompleksi İkmal İnşaatı |language=Turkish|accessdate=2013-05-29 }} The venue opened officially on October 3, 2013.{{cite news |url=http://www.trtspor.com.tr/Haber.aspx?id=33935 |newspaper=TRT Spor |title=THF Salonu 3 Ekim açılacak |date=2012-09-28 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114222837/http://www.trtspor.com.tr/Haber.aspx?id=33935 |archivedate=2012-11-14 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.gsb.gov.tr/site/haberler.aspx?news=1222 |publisher=Gençlik ve Spor Bakanlığı |title=Türk Hentboluna Amiral Gemisi Salon |language=Turkish |date=2012-10-04 |accessdate=2013-05-29 }}{{cite news |url=http://ankaragercekhaber.net/news.php?readmore=12 |newspaper=Ankara Gerçek Haber |title=Türkiye Hentbol Federasyonu Spor Salonu törenle açıldı… |date=2012-10-05 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} The construction cost of {{Turkish lira}}11 million (approx.US$ 6.145 as of October 2012) was funded by the ministry.{{cite news |url=http://spor.milliyet.com.tr/11-milyon-tl-lik-salon/spor/spordetay/23.05.2012/1544045/default.htm |newspaper=[[Milliyet]] |title=11 milyon TL'lik salon |date=2012-05-23 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }} The venue is situated at Yıldızevler, Hilal neighborhood of [[Çankaya, Ankara|Çankaya]] district in Ankara.{{cite web |url=http://www.federasyonhaberleri.com/hentbol-federasyonu-baskanligi.html |publisher=Federasyon Haberleri |title=Hentbol Federasyonu Başkanlığı |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-30 }} The first event the venue hosted was a match for the [[2013 World Women's Handball Championship qualification playoffs#Group D|2013 World Women's Handball Championship qualification playoffs]] between the national teams of [[Turkey women's national handball team|Turkey]] and [[Azerbaijan women's national handball team|Azerbaijan]] played on the opening day. The tournament's all the Group D matches were held also at the THF Sport Hall. Qualified for the playoff round, the Turkish team will play their [[2013 World Women's Handball Championship qualification playoffs#First leg|first leg match]] against the [[Denmark women's national handball team|Danish nationals]] at the venue.{{cite news |url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/Spor/TumSporlarDiger/2012/12/01/a-milliler-playoffta |newspaper=[[Sabah (newspaper)|Sabah]] |title=A Milliler play-off'ta |date=2012-12-01 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }}{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/digersporlar/23390119.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Rakip Danimarka |date=2013-05-29 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }} The [[Turkey national handball team]] plays their home matches in the [[2014 European Men's Handball Championship qualification#Qualification Phase 2|2014 European Men's Handball Championship Qualification - Phase 2]] at the THF Sport Hall.{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/digersporlar/22941408.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |title=Elemelerde rakip Litvanya |date=2013-04-01 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }} The venue hosts all the [[Turkish Handball Super League|Handball Super League]] and [[Turkish Women's Handball Super League|Women's Handball Super League]] matches scheduled in Ankara.{{cite news |url=http://www.sportstv.com.tr/sampiyon-kim-olacak-2/ |newspaper=Sports TV |title=Hentbol-Şampiyon kim olacak? |date=2013-05-20 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-05-29 }} ==International competitions hosted== * [[2013 World Women's Handball Championship – European qualification]] * [[2014 European Men's Handball Championship qualification]] * [[2014 European Women's Handball Championship qualification]] * [[2015 World Men's Handball Championship – European qualification]] * [[2016 European Men's Handball Championship qualification]] * [[2016 European Women's Handball Championship qualification]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Ankara}} [[Category:Sports venues in Ankara]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Turkey]] [[Category:Handball venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:Çankaya, Ankara]]
